CHIRILAGUA, El Salvador, Nov 07 (IPS) - Neither the central government nor most of El Salvador's 262 municipalities have had the capacity to install enough wastewater treatment plants to prevent it from being discharged directly into the environment.

Read the full story, “Community Efforts Boost Wastewater Treatment in El Salvador - Video”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Community Efforts Boost Wastewater Treatment in El Salvador - Video

articles.description:
DHAKA, Nov 07 (IPS) - Since her childhood, Parveen Begum, 52, has been adding extra salt while eating her meals. However, she did not know that this contributed to high blood pressure.

Read the full story, “High Prevalence of Undetected Hypertension Found in Bangladesh”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: High Prevalence of Undetected Hypertension Found in Bangladesh

articles.description:
NEW YORK, Nov 07 (IPS) - There are five measures the Israeli government, along with the US and Saudi Arabia, should put in place to move the peace process forward.

First, Israel must limit its ground invasion to northern Gaza, as a large-scale war will inevitably inflict massive destruction and thousands of casualties on both sides, especially Palestinian civilians, and put the lives of the hostages at a much greater risk.

Read the full story, “Where Do We Go Once the Israel-Hamas War Ends? - PART II”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Where Do We Go Once the Israel-Hamas War Ends? - PART II

articles.description:
PURI, India, Nov 07 (IPS) - For more than 33 years, a group of strong-willed women from the village of Tandahara, India have kept their homes and village safe and plan to continue despite the unrelenting impacts of increasingly severe monsoons.  The sun is high in the noon sky—humidity unrelenting at 95 percent in this Indian sea-coast village. The monsoon has been deficient; rice paddies are yellowing on the edges from the salty surf misting in on them. Waves now break barely 200 metres from the farms and homes.

Read the full story, “The Relentless Struggles of India's Seawall Mammas”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Relentless Struggles of India's Seawall Mammas

articles.description:
Since the beginning of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the human rights situation within Russia itself has deteriorated significantly. Mariana Katzarova, the first UN Human Rights Council-appointed expert on human rights in Russia, spoke about the worsening conditions in her report presented to the UN General Assembly last month in New York.

Read the full story, “Russians not collectively to blame for Ukraine war: Human rights expert”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Russians not collectively to blame for Ukraine war: Human rights expert

articles.description:
The war between rival militaries in Sudan is growing in scope and brutality, having driven almost six million people from their homes since it erupted in April and worsening an already complex humanitarian emergency, the UN refugee agency (UNHCR) warned on Tuesday.

Read the full story, “Sudan war turning ‘homes into cemeteries’: UNHCR”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Sudan war turning ‘homes into cemeteries’: UNHCR

articles.description:
The world risks failing the 880 million people living the world’s Least Developed Countries if soaring debt and a chronic lack of international funds prevent them from getting ahead.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: UNCTAD development finance call, Nepal quake update, religious freedom in Nicaragua”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: UNCTAD development finance call, Nepal quake update, religious freedom in Nicaragua

articles.description:
Tuberculosis (TB) response is bouncing back from disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, but more effort is needed to end the disease, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

Read the full story, “More action needed to write ‘final chapter’ of TB”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: More action needed to write ‘final chapter’ of TB

articles.description:
A month since Hamas militants killed 1,400 people in Israel, taking over 240 hostage, and as the Israeli offensive into Gaza continues which has led to thousands of civilian deaths, UN humanitarians on Tuesday issued a heartfelt appeal for access to the enclave.

Read the full story, “Israel-Palestine crisis: UN humanitarians plead for ‘access, access, access’”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Israel-Palestine crisis: UN humanitarians plead for ‘access, access, access’

articles.description:
Nov 06 (IPS) - The author is an Afghanistan-based female journalist, trained with Finnish support before the Taliban take-over. Her identity is withheld for security reasons“When the sun rises in the morning, I see the light but I don't feel like I'm having a bright day. I think about how different these days are from our past days”.

Read the full story, “Amidst Tears and Grief, Afghan Women Call Out To the World”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Amidst Tears and Grief, Afghan Women Call Out To the World

articles.description:
ROME, Nov 06 (IPS) - Of the many things one might associate with a modern teenager, passion for wholegrain food is probably not the first that comes to mind. An innovative school-meals project in Rwanda, however, has young people singing its praises.

Read the full story, “Fighting Malnutrition and Changing Mindsets in Rwanda”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Fighting Malnutrition and Changing Mindsets in Rwanda

articles.description:
NEW YORK, Nov 06 (IPS) - Since the 1967 Six Day War, many efforts have been made to reach a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians through mediation conducted by an impartial mediator, face-to face negotiations, international conferences, offering incentives, back-channel talks, interim agreements (in particular the Oslo Accords), and occasionally by an influential party exerting pressure on both sides, especially the US.

Read the full story, “Where Do We Go Once the Israel-Hamas War Ends? - Part I”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Where Do We Go Once the Israel-Hamas War Ends? - Part I

articles.description:
BULAWAYO, Nov 06 (IPS) - Zimbabwe’s recent election has exposed weak gender policies both at the political party and governmental levels as women were sidelined despite the fact that they make up more than half of the 6.5 million electorate.

Read the full story, “Zimbabwe's Election Widens Gender Gap in Politics”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Zimbabwe's Election Widens Gender Gap in Politics

articles.description:
Even though women have made extraordinary contributions to Islamic civilization, in many countries they are still being left behind, UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed said during a speech in Saudi Arabia on Monday.

Read the full story, “Women in Islam: Mohammed calls for action on education, empowerment and peace”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Women in Islam: Mohammed calls for action on education, empowerment and peace

articles.description:
UN agencies in Nepal continue their response to the deadly earthquake that struck western parts of the country over the weekend, claiming 153 lives, injuring over 330 and forcing thousands to spend nights in the open amid freezing temperatures.

Read the full story, “Nepal quake: UN response continues, as aftershocks leave families traumatized”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Nepal quake: UN response continues, as aftershocks leave families traumatized

articles.description:
As the conflict intensifies in Gaza, with risk of spillover to the wider region, UN Secretary-General António Guterres on Monday underlined the need to support a $1.2 billion humanitarian appeal to help nearly three million people across the Occupied Palestinian Territory.

Read the full story, “Gaza: ‘Unfolding catastrophe’ makes humanitarian ceasefire more urgent”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gaza: ‘Unfolding catastrophe’ makes humanitarian ceasefire more urgent

articles.description:
The war between rival militaries in Sudan has interrupted encouraging signs of dialogue between Sudan and neighbouring South Sudan and “effectively put on hold” talks over disputed Abyei, senior UN officials told the Security Council on Monday.

Read the full story, “Sudan crisis has ‘effectively put on hold’ political dispute over Abyei”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Sudan crisis has ‘effectively put on hold’ political dispute over Abyei

articles.description:
Sudan’s children need immediate support from the international community to prevent the country from becoming “another forgotten humanitarian catastrophe” said the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) on Monday.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Sudan and South Sudan updates, Ukraine heritage under fire in Odesa”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Sudan and South Sudan updates, Ukraine heritage under fire in Odesa

articles.description:
Although current agrifood systems provide nourishment and sustain economies, they also impose huge hidden costs on health and the environment - the equivalent of at least $10 trillion annually - a new report by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) has revealed.

Read the full story, “FAO report reveals hidden costs of agrifood systems”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: FAO report reveals hidden costs of agrifood systems

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
SUBSCRIBER+EXCLUSIVE REPORTING – CIA Director Bill Burns is in the Middle East as part of a Biden Administration push to ease tensions in the region [...] More 
The post Director Burns’ Middle East Mission appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: Director Burns’ Middle East Mission
Turn Your Rising Home Equity Into Cash You Can Use
Dream Big with a Home Equity Loan
Want Cash Out of Your Home? Here Are Your Best Options

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: The Biden administration is appealing a judge's decision to block a rule imposing new restrictions on asylum seekers at the US-Mexico border. The rule, which aims to limit asylum for migrants who entered the US illegally or passed through other nations without seeking protection, was deemed to violate federal immigration law. The government argues that the rule includes exceptions and is therefore valid. Immigrant advocacy groups represented by the ACLU challenged the rule.
articles.title: Biden administration urges US court to uphold asylum restrictions

articles.description: China and the United States engaged in arms control talks in Washington this week, marking the first such meeting since the Obama administration. While the discussions were described as constructive, no follow-up meeting has been scheduled. The talks aim to set a positive tone ahead of a possible meeting between Presidents Joe Biden and Xi Jinping next week. The US is concerned about China's nuclear arsenal expansion, but China did not provide substantive responses to US requests for transparency on its nuclear forces.
articles.title: US says China reveals little in arms control talks

articles.description: Starting from Wednesday, a ban on the recreational use and possession of nitrous oxide, commonly known as 'laughing gas', will be in effect in Britain. The government cited the drug's contribution to anti-social behavior and health hazards as reasons for the ban. Offenders could face fines or up to two years in prison, and the maximum punishment for dealing the drug has been doubled to 14 years. Nitrous oxide is the third most commonly used drug by 16 to 24-year-olds and can lead to anaemia, nerve damage, or paralysis with heavy use.
articles.title: Britain bans 'laughing gas' to curb anti-social behaviour

articles.description: Vivek Ramaswamy, a Republican presidential candidate, stated that he would withdraw the United States from the Paris climate accord if elected. He believes that the climate change agenda is a hoax and that global warming is not an existential risk. Ramaswamy argues that the US should not be part of the Paris agreement and that policies restricting fossil fuel usage are more harmful to humans than climate change itself. He also emphasized the importance of focusing on domestic policies rather than being the "global police.
articles.title: Republican climate skeptic Ramaswamy to quit Paris deal if elected

articles.description: Turkish parliament has reportedly removed Coca-Cola and Nestle products from its restaurants citing their alleged support for Israel. However, there was no clear indication of how these companies showed their support for Israel's war effort. Last month, Nestle had temporarily closed one of its production plants in Israel as a precautionary measure, making it the first consumer products giant to respond to the ongoing conflict.
articles.title: Turkey House bans Coke, Nestle from its eateries over Gaza

articles.description: The Secretary-General of the United Nations, Antonio Guterres, announced on Monday that during the month-long conflict between Israel and Hamas, 89 UNRWA employees who were providing aid to Palestinian refugees in Gaza were killed. Guterres stated that this is the highest number of casualties ever recorded among UNRWA staff during a similar period. He further added that many of these workers lost their lives along with their family members.
articles.title: With 89 staffers dead, Gaza war turns out to be deadliest for UN

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated that Israel would consider temporary halts in the fighting in Gaza to allow humanitarian aid to enter or to permit the release of hostages held by Hamas militants. However, Netanyahu maintained that Israel would not agree to a ceasefire unless all individuals held captive in the Hamas-controlled Palestinian territory were released.
articles.title: Israel open to 'little pauses' in Gaza fighting, says Netanyahu

articles.description: Pakistan Muslim League Nawaz (PML-N) and a Karachi-based party, Muttahida Qaumi Movement Pakistan (MQM-P), have declared that they will be jointly participating in the upcoming general elections scheduled on February 8. The MQM-P delegation had a meeting with the PML-N leader Nawaz Sharif at the party's Model Town secretariat in Lahore, which led to this development.
articles.title: PML-N, MQM-P to contest February 8 polls jointly in Pakistan

articles.description: A shark pup has been born through parthenogenesis at Brookfield Zoo near Chicago. The baby epaulette shark hatched during the summer, and its mother has never shared a tank with a male. Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction. The birth adds to the zoo's diversity of life. The shark pup is currently two months old and measures approximately 6 inches. It has been eating well and will soon be visible to zoo visitors.In contrast, the epaulette shark pup has fared better and has recently made its public debut, captivating visitors in the zoo's Living Coast exhibit.
articles.title: Brookfield zoo celebrates birth of shark pup through parthenogenesis

articles.description: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene has admitted that Republicans prioritize media appearances and online discussions over actual work. She also expressed frustration with Republicans in Congress for not holding the government accountable. However, her own priorities have been questioned as she focuses on censuring Representative Rashida Tlaib instead of addressing the impending government shutdown. Greene's initial censure resolution was unsupported and now a revised resolution is set to be voted on. Meanwhile, other House Republicans are focusing on spending bills.
articles.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene criticizes Republicans' focus on media over accountability

articles.description: American YouTuber MrBeast's video about constructing 100 wells in Africa has received mixed responses. Kenyan activists and journalists pointed out the failures of the Kenyan government. Despite potential backlash, MrBeast believes the wells will provide clean drinking water for 500,000 people in Cameroon, Kenya, Somalia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe. The associated fundraising campaign has raised over $300,000. MrBeast also donated supplies to Kenyan schools and built a bridge and donated bicycles to Zimbabwean villages.
articles.title: American youtuber MrBeast's Africa well-drilling video sparks debate

articles.description: The European Space Agency (ESA) is organizing a competition to develop a robotic cargo capsule for transportation to and from the International Space Station (ISS). The capsule will be operated as a commercial venture by the competition winner, who will receive financial support and technical assistance from ESA. The selected company may also be tasked with upgrading the capsule for transporting ESA astronauts and potentially traveling to other destinations, such as the Moon. This competition model is inspired by NASA's successful approach of working with private companies.
articles.title: European space agency to develop commercial cargo capsule

articles.description: A fire in an informal immigrant neighborhood in Coronel, Chile, resulted in the death of 14 individuals, most of whom were children. The victims are believed to be undocumented Venezuelan immigrants who had recently arrived in the area. The cause of the fire is still being determined, but preliminary reports suggest that it may have been sparked by a fire from a handmade stove. Chilean President Gabriel Boric expressed his condolences and called for reflection on how society treats immigrants.
articles.title: Fire in Chile immigrant neighborhood kills 14, including eight children

articles.description: Portuguese Prime Minister Antonio Costa has announced his resignation following his involvement in a corruption probe. Costa's chief of staff was arrested earlier in the day as part of the investigation, which focuses on alleged malfeasance, corruption, and influence peddling relating to lithium mine concessions and green energy projects. Costa, who has been the country's Socialist leader since 2015, defended his innocence and expressed his trust in the justice system.
articles.title: Portuguese prime minister resigns after being caught up in corruption probe

articles.description: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy has proposed extending an export ban on Ukrainian natural gas for the whole of 2024, a presidential decree said on Tuesday. The export ban was introduced soon after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 and was then extended to cover 2023. The decree also urged the government to increase the capacity of Ukraine's gas transmission system "to ensure the import of natural gas and its accumulation in underground gas storage facilities".
articles.title: Zelenskiy proposes extending Ukraine's gas export ban

articles.description: Houston Texans rookie quarterback CJ Stroud, after leading his team to victory against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, used his post-game press conference to draw attention to his incarcerated father. Stroud expressed the challenges of balancing his role as a family man, a football player, and helping his father, who is serving a 38-year to life sentence. He highlighted the need for criminal justice reform and the deplorable conditions in some prisons, emphasizing the importance of treating prisoners as humans. Stroud hopes his father will one day be able to attend his games.
articles.title: US 'Criminal justice system is corrupt' says footballer CJ Stroud

articles.description: Former Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett engaged in a discussion with MSNBC host Katy Tur and the international community regarding the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Many global community members criticized Israel's response to the recent Hamas attack, accusing them of excessive force and even genocide. Bennett argued that Israel is held to a different standard and posed a hypothetical scenario to highlight this point. He opposed a two-state solution and claimed that Israel had previously given Gaza to the Palestinians, but they used it to attack Israel instead.
articles.title: ​Former Israeli PM Naftali Bennett defends Israel's actions amidst international criticism

articles.description: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak presented his government's agenda to tackle crime, boost economic growth, and address climate change. The agenda, delivered by King Charles to lawmakers in parliament, aims to differentiate the ruling Conservative Party from the opposition Labour Party ahead of the expected election next year. The government plans to toughen sentences for violent offenders, reduce the burden of climate targets on households, and prioritize long-term decision-making. The King's Speech also included promises to address inflation, boost economic growth and tackle illegal migration.
articles.title: UK's Sunak sets out pre-election agenda in King's Speech

articles.description: The proposed amnesty bill in Spain could result in the convictions or charges against over a thousand Catalan politicians, officials, and activists being wiped off the slate. The bill was put forward by the Socialist Party in exchange for support from Catalan separatist parties. However, the bill has sparked controversy. Supporters of the amnesty believe it would bring moral justice and establish a more constructive relationship between Catalonia and the national government.
articles.title: Young Catalan separatist sees justice, reparation in proposed amnesty

articles.description: On Tuesday, NATO officially declared the suspension of a significant security treaty dating back to the Cold War era in response to Russia's withdrawal from the agreement. The alliance has announced that its member states who were signatories to the treaty are now pausing their involvement in the pact. The Treaty of Conventional Armed Forces in Europe, which most of NATO's 31 allies have signed, was originally designed to prevent the amassing of military forces by Cold War adversaries near or on shared borders.
articles.title: Nato announces formal suspension of cold war-era security treaty after Russia's pullout

articles.description: Russia retaliated against Ukraine by launching missiles and drones at the southern Ukrainian city of Odesa, injuring five people and damaging a 19th-century art museum. Ukraine's 128th Mountain Assault Brigade reported 19 soldiers killed in a Russian strike on a medal ceremony. The commander of the brigade has been removed from his post, and an investigation is underway. Ukraine's top military commander also lost a close aide in an explosion. Odesa's Fine Arts Museum, a UnescoWorld Heritage Site, suffered damage in the attack.
articles.title: Russian drones and missiles attack Odesa, damaging an art museum

articles.description: The United States and China held talks on nuclear arms control, marking the first meeting on this issue since the Obama administration. The talks aim to ease mistrust between the two countries ahead of an expected presidential summit. The US has expressed concern over China's growing nuclear arsenal. While no breakthroughs were expected, the talks are seen as a way to manage the relationship and prevent conflict. China currently has over 500 operational nuclear warheads, with estimates suggesting they could have over 1,000 by 2030. The US has around 3,700 nuclear warheads.
articles.title: US, China hold rare talks on nuclear arms control

articles.description: UN peacekeepers deployed in the Democratic Republic of Congo are determined to protect civilians against rebels, despite accusations from many Congolese that the UN forces have failed in their mission. The joint operation, known as Springbok, was launched by the UN's MONUSCO mission and the Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (FARDC) to prevent the M23 rebels from taking control of Goma. The citizens movement Lucha has called for a sit-in in Goma to demand the departure of the UN mission and its troops.
articles.title: UN force deploys for operation 'Springbok' to save DR Congo civlians

articles.description: The WHO said on Sunday that it had documented more than 100 attacks on the healthcare system in Gaza, as the Israeli military said Hamas fighters were using two additional hospitals in the enclave to conceal their operations. A week after Israeli officials said they had identified Gaza's largest hospital al-Shifa as being used by Hamas for underground command centres, the military's chief spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari presented images and videos of what he said was the opening to a Hamas tunnel under Sheikh Hamad Hospital, north of Gaza City.
articles.title: 'Besides al-Shifa, Hamas base in 2 more hospitals'

articles.description: Hospitals in the Gaza Strip are on the brink of collapse, with doctors and nurses having to make difficult decisions about who receives medical treatment due to a lack of electricity and basic supplies. Patients are being denied ventilators and resuscitation, while children undergo amputations and brain surgeries without anesthesia or clean water. The conditions are the worst ever seen by veterans of wartime medicine in Gaza, with hospitals crumbling under Israeli bombardment and severe fuel shortages.
articles.title: Gaza medics face hard choice of who lives, who dies

articles.description: US secretary of state Antony Blinken wrapped up a gruelling West Asia diplomatic tour on Monday in Turkiye after only limited success in efforts to forge a regional consensus on how best to ease civilian suffering in Gaza as Israel intensifies its war against Hamas. In Ankara, Blinken met with foreign minister Hakan Fidan following a frantic weekend of travel that took him from Israel to Jordan, the occupied West Bank, Cyprus and Iraq, to build support for the Biden administration's proposal for "humanitarian pauses" to Israel's relentless military campaign in Gaza.
articles.title: Blinken wraps up West Asia tour in Turkiye with little success on pause

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Four soldiers, including a Pakistan army lieutenant-colonel, were killed in an exchange of fire with suspected militants in the Khyber tribal district. Security forces launched an operation in Tirah Valley after receiving reports of militants in the area. As troops closed in, a group of militants was intercepted, leading to a shootout that resulted in the deaths of the soldiers and three militants. This incident follows recent terrorist attacks on a Pakistani Air Force base and security personnel in other regions of the country.
articles.title: Pakistan army officer, 3 soldiers die in operation near Durand Line

articles.description: Israeli forces have cut off northern Gaza from the rest of the territory and launched intense air strikes, preparing for a push into Gaza City. The death toll in Palestine has exceeded 10,000, with over 4,100 children and 2,600 women among the casualties. Israel has vowed to crush Hamas, and the war is expected to escalate as troops enter Gaza City. The Israeli military said it had successfully encircled the north and south of Gaza, and ground troops have taken over a Hamas compound.
articles.title: Israel cuts off north Gaza as Palestinian toll tops 10,000

articles.description: Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi is set to attend a summit in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, organized by the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC), to address the Israel-Hamas war. This will be Raisi's first visit to Saudi Arabia since the two countries restored diplomatic relations earlier this year. The OIC has been vocal in condemning attacks on Gaza, and the summit is scheduled to take place after an emergency meeting of Arab League leaders in Riyadh. Saudi Arabia is concerned about the potential impact of the war on its reform agenda.
articles.title: Iran president to attend summit in Saudi on Gaza: source

articles.description: Jordan has stated that it is considering all options in response to Israel's failure to differentiate between military and civilian targets in its attack on Gaza. Prime Minister Bisher al Khasawneh did not provide details on what actions Jordan would take. Last week, Jordan recalled its ambassador from Israel and declared Israel's ambassador persona non grata. Jordan is reviewing its economic, security, and political ties with Israel and may suspend further steps in implementing the peace treaty if the situation worsens.
articles.title: Jordan says 'all options' open as Gaza conflict intensifies

articles.description: A British Sikh man, Jatinder Singh, who claimed he was barred from jury duty because he was carrying a kirpan, has been invited by the authorities to discuss the matter further. Singh's discharge was initially attributed to a surplus of jury members on the day. The His Majesty's Courts and Tribunals Service (HMCTS) has apologized and invited Singh to ensure their policies are correctly applied. The incident has prompted a Sikh MP to seek a review into the broader implications for the community.
articles.title: British Sikh invited to discuss incident involving kirpan in UK court

articles.description: Former US President Donald Trump clashed with the judge during his testimony in a New York civil fraud case. The judge admonished Trump to keep his answers short and requested his lawyer to control him. Trump complained about the trial brought by Democrats and denied allegations of fraudulent financial statements. He also criticized the case as "election interference" and compared it to situations in "third world countries." Trump's testimony follows that of his sons, Donald Jr. and Eric, who blamed accountants for any inaccuracies in the company's financial statements.
articles.title: Judge chides Trump as ex-president testifies in civil fraud trial: 'This is not a political rally'

articles.description: Europe's top space official has announced that Europe is ready to challenge the private sector in developing rockets and supporting space entrepreneurs. This move is aimed at catching up with the growth of Elon Musk's SpaceX. The announcement was made at a ministerial meeting in Seville, Spain, where efforts were being made to strengthen Europe's struggling launcher programs and boost space exploration. The European Space Agency hopes that this challenge will stimulate new commercial space transportation services and create a new market for European space entrepreneurs.
articles.title: Europe to issue launcher 'challenge' in Seville space talks

articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin has claimed that Western weapons supplied to Ukraine are being sold on the illegal arms market and ending up in the hands of the Taliban in the Middle East. Western powers have sent Ukraine billions of dollars worth of weapons since Russia's intervention in Ukraine in 2014. While Ukraine insists it maintains tight control over these weapons, concerns have been raised about the potential for corruption and the illegal arms trade.
articles.title: Putin says some Western weapons for Ukraine are ending up in the Taliban's hands

articles.description: Hamas militants fired 16 rockets from Lebanon towards northern Israel, in response to Israeli aggression in the Gaza Strip. The Israeli army reported about 30 projectiles fired at northern Israel from Lebanon and retaliated. The death toll in Gaza has surpassed 10,000 since the start of the war triggered by Hamas' attack on Israel. Tensions have been high between Israel and Lebanon since the attack, with regular exchanges of attacks between Hezbollah and Israel.
articles.title: Hamas says launched 16 rockets from Lebanon at Israel

articles.description: Nobel Peace Prize winner Narges Mohammadi has begun a hunger strike in an Iranian jail in protest against the lack of access to medical care. The women's rights advocate, who won the award earlier this month, has reportedly been denied treatment for heart and lung conditions as she refused to wear a headscarf during a hospital visit. Mohammadi is currently serving multiple sentences totalling 12 years imprisonment on charges including spreading propaganda against the Islamic Republic.
articles.title: Jailed Iranian Nobel laureate Mohammadi goes on hunger strike

articles.description: Israeli forces have intensified their airstrikes on northern Gaza, cutting it off from the rest of the territory. This is seen as a prelude to a push into Gaza city, which is expected to result in even more casualties. The Palestinian death toll has already surpassed 10,000, with the majority being civilians. The situation in Gaza is dire, with food, medicine, fuel, and water running low, and the UN-run shelters are overcrowded. The international community has called for a ceasefire, but Israel has rejected these calls.
articles.title: Israeli forces cut off north Gaza as Palestinian death toll from monthlong war passes 10,000

articles.description: China News: BEIJING: The leaders of Australia and China joked about the relative cuteness of pandas and Tasmanian devils on Monday in a largely symbolic meeting t.
articles.title: Australian and Chinese leaders talk pandas and wine as ties improve despite disagreements

articles.description: China has appointed Vice-Premier He Lifeng to lead a new Communist Party organization focused on the financial sector. He emphasized the need to strengthen the Party's leadership in finance and called for increased inspection and rectification of financial systems. He will also be visiting the United States as Beijing's main representative for China-US economic and trade affairs. However, he is not responsible for technology or manufacturing, which are handled by other Vice-Premiers.
articles.title: Head of Communist Party finance body : Vice Premier He Lifeng's new title

articles.description: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken expressed confidence in progress being made on Sweden's Nato membership bid after talks with his Turkish counterpart in Ankara. Turkey's President Tayyip Erdogan submitted the bill ratifying Sweden's membership to parliament, a move that has been delayed for months. Blinken stated that there was a shared commitment between Ankara and Washington to ensure Sweden's inclusion in the alliance. Sweden and Finland applied to join Nato last year for security reasons following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
articles.title: Blinken says convinced of Sweden's NATO membership progress after Ankara visit

articles.description: Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds is expected to endorse Florida Governor Ron DeSantis for the 2024 presidential race, providing a potential boost to DeSantis, who trails behind former President Donald Trump in the Republican nomination race. Reynolds will appear at a DeSantis rally in Iowa on Monday. DeSantis has focused heavily on Iowa, believing a strong showing in the state could help him close the gap with Trump. The Trump campaign responded to the endorsement news by criticizing Reynolds for previously declaring neutrality in the race.
articles.title: Iowa governor Reynolds to endorse DeSantis' presidential candidacy: Sources

articles.description: More than 20 people were killed in Sudan after shells hit a market in a suburb of the capital, Khartoum. The fighting between army chief Abdel Fattah al-Burhan and his former deputy Mohamed Hamdan Daglo has been ongoing since April. The conflict has resulted in over 10,000 deaths and 5.5 million people being displaced, according to estimates by the United Nations. The actual toll is believed to be higher as many of the wounded and killed do not reach hospitals or morgues.
articles.title: More than 20 killed in Sudan after shell hits Khartoum market: NGO

articles.description: TEL AVIV: US officials said they've privately outlined several steps to Israel to reduce civilian casualties in its military campaign in the Gaza Stri.
articles.title: US outlines steps for Israel to cut civilian deaths

articles.description: Ohio voters will decide on Tuesday whether to add explicit protections for abortion rights to the state's constitution. The referendum will determine whether the constitution guarantees the freedom to make reproductive decisions, including abortion. The US Supreme Court revoked the national right to abortion last year, leaving it up to individual states to decide. Ohio currently has a law that would ban abortions after a heartbeat is detected, but it is temporarily suspended due to legal challenges.
articles.title: Ohio vote tests abortion question one year ahead of 2024 race

articles.description: The office of President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday chastised Ukraine's top military commander for publicly declaring the war at a stalemate, suggesting the comments would help the Russian invasion. It was a striking public rebuke that signaled an emerging rift between the military and civilian leadership at a challenging time for Ukraine. The public censure of Zaluzhny came a day after the president's office replaced one of his deputies, the head of special operations forces, who after his firing said he had been blindsided by the dismissal.
articles.title: In rift with military, Zelensky slams top gen for 'war at stalemate' remark

articles.description: Middle East News: Qatar's foreign ministry said on Sunday that without a "period of calm" in Gaza its mediators would not be able to secure the release of Israeli hosta.
articles.title: Qatar: Hostage releases need 'period of calm', talks are at risk

articles.description: PM Netanyahu disciplined on Sunday a junior member of his cabinet who appeared to voice openness to the idea of Israel carrying out a nuclear strike on Gaza. Netanyahu's office said in a statement that the minister concerned - heritage minister Amihay Eliyahu from a far-right party in the coalition government - had been suspended from cabinet meetings "until further notice".  "Eliyahu's statements are not based in reality. Israel and the IDF (military) are operating in accordance with the highest standards of international law," Netanyahu's office said.
articles.title: Netanyahu's minister says nuking Gaza an option, draws Bibi's ire

articles.description: Protesters gathered outside the residence of Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu to express their anger at the failures that led to last month's deadly attack by Hamas gunmen. The protest coincided with a poll showing that over three-quarters of Israelis believe Netanyahu should resign. Netanyahu has not taken personal responsibility for the failures that allowed the surprise assault, which has led to growing public fury and criticism of the government's response. A majority of Israelis blame Netanyahu for the attack, according to the poll.
articles.title: Anger against Netanyahu rises as Israelis amass outside his home

articles.description: A hostage situation at Hamburg airport in Germany came to an end after 18 hours. The man, who had driven his vehicle through the gates with his 4-year-old daughter inside, was arrested and the girl is unharmed. The airport had been closed since Saturday night when the armed man broke through a gate and fired shots. The man's wife had previously reported a child abduction, and it is believed to be a custody battle. No one was injured during the standoff.
articles.title: Hostage crisis at German airport ends after 18 hrs

articles.description: President Biden is trailing behind Donald Trump in five out of six battleground states, according to polls by the New York Times and Siena College. Voters have doubts about Biden's age and are dissatisfied with his handling of the economy and other issues. Biden is only ahead in Wisconsin, while Trump leads in Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, and Pennsylvania. The polls also show that voters across income levels feel Biden's policies have hurt them personally, while they credit Trump's policies for helping them.
articles.title: Trump leads in 5 of 6 key battleground US states as voters blast Biden: Polls

articles.description: Elon Musk on Saturday unveiled details of his new AI tool called "Grok", which can access X in real time and will be initially available to the social.
articles.title: Musk teases AI chatbot 'Grok' with real-time access to X

articles.description: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has stated that the Palestinian Authority should have a central role in the future of Gaza. Blinken made the comments during his visit to the region amid escalating tensions over Israel's war with Hamas. He met with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas in Ramallah and then traveled to Iraq. Blinken also discussed the need for humanitarian pauses in the fighting and addressed the threats from Iranian-aligned militias. He is seeking discussions on how Gaza could be governed after the destruction of Hamas.
articles.title: Blinken says Palestinian voices key to Gaza future

articles.description: More than 300 Americans and their families have been evacuated from Gaza, but negotiations are ongoing for the release of hostages taken by Hamas. The exact number of remaining US citizens in Gaza is unknown. Efforts are being made to resume evacuations of injured Gazans and foreign passport holders through the Rafah crossing. President Joe Biden has called for a pause in hostilities to allow hostages to be released, and the White House supports a humanitarian pause for aid deliveries to Gaza. Over 9,770 Palestinians have been killed in the conflict.
articles.title: More than 300 Americans got out of Gaza, more remain, White House says

articles.description: Four civilians, including three children, were killed in an Israeli airstrike in southern Lebanon. The strike was carried out by the Israeli military in response to a strike launched by the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, which resulted in the death of one Israeli. The clashes between Israeli troops and Hezbollah militants along the Lebanon-Israel border have been escalating since the start of the Hamas-Israel war. The death toll of civilians on the Lebanese side has now reached 14, with Hezbollah warning of retaliation if Lebanese civilians are targeted.
articles.title: A woman and 3 children are killed by an Israeli airstrike in south Lebanon, local officials say

articles.description: The Israel Defence Forces (IDF) have shared video evidence of Hamas rocket launchers being placed near a children's swimming pool and a playground in the northern Gaza Strip. The IDF has accused Hamas of committing war crimes by deliberately placing rocket launchers near civilian sites. The videos and pictures provided by the IDF show rocket launchers positioned within a residential neighborhood and a children's playground. The IDF has condemned Hamas for using the civilian population as a human shield for terror purposes.
articles.title: Israel uncovers Hamas rocket launchers next to children's pool, playground

articles.description: Four Palestinians were killed during Israeli military raids in the occupied West Bank, according to the Palestinian health ministry and Israeli army. The violence occurred amidst the Israel-Hamas war. Two men were killed in an attack by Israeli forces in Abu Dis, while a third Palestinian, allegedly affiliated with the Islamic State group, was shot dead in a fire exchange. Another Palestinian was killed in Nuba during clashes with Israeli soldiers. Since the start of the war, over 150 Palestinians have been killed in the West Bank, and over 1,000 have been arrested.
articles.title: Israel forces kill four Palestinians in West Bank

articles.description: Israel cut internet and phone lines in the Gaza Strip Sunday night, for the third time since the start of the Israel-Hamas war on October 7, telecoms firm Paltel said. "We regret to announce the complete shutdown of communications and internet services in Gaza after the Israeli side disconnected the servers," Paltel said in a statement. However, soon Israeli army launched intense bombardment on Gaza city and other nearby zones which could be heard in Rafah.
articles.title: Internet, phone lines cut again in Gaza: Telecoms firm

articles.description: Israeli President Isaac Herzog accepted the credentials of newly appointed US Ambassador to Israel Jack Lew. The appointment was fast-tracked due to the escalating conflict between Hamas and Israel in Gaza. During the credential-receiving ceremony, President Herzog expressed gratitude for the support of the United States and emphasized the importance of the friendship between the two countries. Ambassador Lew acknowledged the challenging times and pledged to prioritize working towards securing the release of hostages held by Hamas.
articles.title: US envoy to Israel submits credentials to Pres Herzog, takes charge

articles.description: External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar spoke with his Iranian counterpart, Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, to discuss the serious situation arising from the Israel-Hamas conflict. "Spoke today with Iranian Foreign Minister Amir Abdollahian. Discussed the grave situation in West Asia and the concern of the international community," the external affairs minister posted on 'X'. "Conveyed the importance of preventing escalation and providing humanitarian support. Agreed to stay in touch," he said.
articles.title: Israel-Hamas conflict: EAM Jaishankar speaks to Iranian counterpart, discusses 'grave' situation

articles.description: Three Iranians who were allegedly agents of Israel's Mossad spy agency have been detained in a joint operation with the Taliban in Afghanistan, according to state television in Iran. It said that the detainees were said to be planning kamikaze drone attacks from the Afghan border into Iran. News of the arrests came after a Taliban delegation arrived in Tehran on Saturday for meetings with top officials including Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian.
articles.title: 'Israeli spies' held in joint operation with Afghanistan: Iran

articles.description: Every November, Mexico holds its largest public celebration: Día de los Muertos, a fusion of Roman Catholic and Indigenous rituals that honor and remember deceased loved ones. Far from a mournful affair, the holiday is a time of celebration and warmth.
articles.title: Stories behind Day of the Dead

articles.description: Every November 1st and 2nd, Mexico holds its largest public celebration: Día de los Muertos, or Day of the Dead, a fusion of Roman Catholic and Indigenous rituals that honor and remember deceased loved ones. Far from a mournful affair, the holiday is a time of celebration and warmth. Correspondent Enrique Acevedo talks with Mexico City's minister of culture Claudia Curiel De Icaza about the city's celebrations; with acclaimed chef Elena Reygadas about baking traditional pan de muerto; and with author Regina Marchi, who has documented the holiday's growing popularity on both sides of the border in her book, "Day of the Dead in the U.S.A."
articles.title: Mexico's Day of the Dead celebrations

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.description: Flooding has hit dozens of towns in northern France, leaving roads sometimes only passable in boats and dozens of schools closed, authorities said Tuesday.

articles.description: Several anti-semitic incidents were recorded in the Caucasus, a Russian region made up of three majority-Muslim republics, on October 28 and 29. In one of these incidents, a mob stormed an airport to search for "Israelis" and "Jews" on a flight from Tel Aviv. Our team spoke to a researcher who said that while these incidents were sparked by the war between Hamas and Israel, there is also a more complex regional context.
articles.title: In wave of anti-Semitism, Russian mob storms plane 'looking for Israelis'

articles.author: Joanna YORK
articles.description: As the need for medical care in Gaza soars, accessing working hospitals and health centres is becoming more and more difficult. Alternative solutions such as evacuating patients overseas and setting up field hospitals are under way, but may offer little hope if there is no end to fighting in the Palestinian enclave, experts say.

articles.description: Since October 7, Gazan journalist Madhat Hajjaj has sent us dozens of eyewitness reports as the Israeli bombing continues. In a video sent to the Observateurs editorial team on November 6 from the Al-Shifa Hospital, he said that "people are fighting for a sip of water" after a night of unprecedented bombardment. The Palestinian Authority has accused the Israeli army of targeting hospitals, bakeries, generators and water tanks.

articles.description: Around half the population in Gaza are under 18. That's around 1.1 million children packed into one of the most densely populated territories in the world. The UN says the majority are displaced, staying with their families in overcrowded shelters or camped in hospital grounds. The Hamas-run health authority says at least 4,104 children have been killed in Israeli strikes since the start of the war. In this edition of Perspective, we focus on the work of a charity set up to help children impacted by war. It's called INARA (International network for aid, relief and assistance) and was founded by former CNN correspondent Arwa Damon. She spoke to FRANCE 24's Gavin Lee.
articles.title: Former CNN correspondent Arwa Damon on helping children in Gaza

articles.author: M.L. Nestel
articles.description:
She tried to censure and it came up short. 
Now she's shaming the names who didn't vote in favor. 
Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) had willed a resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) for her attendance of a protest opposing the war in Gaza. 
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
"List of feckless Republicans that voted WITH Democrats to table my censure resolution against Rashida Tlaib," Greene said on Wednesday. "This is why Republicans NEVER do anything to stop the communists Democrats or ever hold anyone accountable!! PATHETIC."

She created a social media thread naming some of her friends in the House who didn't have what it took to vote with her. 
They include current House Speaker Mike Johnson, Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX), and Rep. Ken Buck (R-CO) who announced he wasn't running for reelection. 

	Earlier in the week, Greene preemptively lashed out after learning that her effort wasn't gaining a coalition in Congress.
"I want to remind you, this happened on the same day Hezbollah declared a day of immense anger," she said. "And Rashida Tlaib organized with that group. And they did. They did protest, and they did an insurrection into our Capitol complex, stopping Congress and stopping the Senate."
The media was quick to take notice of the lawmaker's swing and miss Wednesday.
"Colleague Kelly Phares rpts 23 GOPers join Dems to table or kill effort to censure Dem MI Rep Tlaib," tweeted Chat Pergram.
Melanie Zanona also tweeted: "motion to table — aka kill — MTG’s resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib just passed the House, with help of 23 Republicans."

And CNN's Manu Raju added that the effort to take on Tlaib quickly died tweeting: "House kills resolution to censure Rashida Tlaib. 23 Republicans voted with Dems. MTG offered the resolution."
articles.title: 'Pathetic': Marjorie Taylor Greene attacks 'feckless Republicans' who voted against her

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
Sen. Tommy Tuberville's (R-AL) blockade appears to be coming to an end, according to an MSNBC report. 
Capitol reporter Ali Vitali said that a group of Republicans were going to take to the Senate floor and force a vote with Democrats to marginalize Tuberville's protest against military promotions that has led to a reduced military readiness for the United States, according to reports.
After a discussion about the absurdity of the protest, host Nicolle Wallace said that she recalled the era when Republicans had to be supportive of the military or they'd be shamed by leaders like Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and the GOP speaker. 
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
Taking to social media, reporter Andrew Desiderio confirmed the reporting, saying that the floor actions will take place tonight, where they will ask for unanimous consent on ending the Tuberville blockade. He said that he was told it would be led by Sen. Dan Sullivan (R-AK). 
The news comes after reports that McConnell threatened Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) over his bill to stop corporations from being able to give money to campaigns. McConnell reportedly pointed to Hawley in the caucus lunch and said he wouldn't be there if it wasn't for the money from his Senate Leadership PAC. He went on to threaten any member who supported the bill with a primary. 
It's the first such action heard about from McConnell since he suffered serious injuries from a series of falls and then appeared to freeze at various public press availabilities.
articles.title: Republicans to join Dems in breaking Tuberville's blockade on military promotions: report

articles.author: M.L. Nestel
articles.description:
He drew a hard line in the sand, stalling hundreds of promotions of military brass. 
That line is budging. 
Officials are fuming at  Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-AL) after it was discovered over the weekend that Marine Corps Commandant Gen. Eric Smith, who had been doubling as both the top No. 1 and No. 2 Marine Corps leader since July, suffered an apparent heart attack and was hospitalized on Sunday — leaving a three-star general to hold the prestigious post, according to a report published by Politico.
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
The potential overextension of Smith and the stalling of more than 300 critical leadership roles was iced out by Tuberville's blockade installed as a protest against the Pentagon's policy to permit time off and reimbursement for abortions.  
Now…
articles.title: Tuberville's military blockade has 'added danger' after top Marine's heart attack: report

House Republicans, lead by newly minted Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA), are demanding that the cost of the aid package to Israel be "offset" by $14 billion in cuts to IRS enforcement funding guaranteed in President Joe Biden's Inflation Reduction Act — which is not only unrelated to the issue at hand, but experts say it would actually increase the deficit.
The fact that Republicans are demanding an increase in tax evasion as their condition of supporting a key U.S. ally's military is not an accident, argued Talking Points Memo's Josh Marshall on MSNBC Tuesday, but a sign of how low the GOP has sunk.
"I have to say, Josh, like, Mike Johnson rolling out, going after the IRS on a must-pass is past even a caricature, I can imagine, of a priority from the Republican House speaker," said anchor Chr…

articles.author: Maya Boddie,  Alternet
articles.description:
After Marine Corps Gen. Eric Smith suffered landed in the hospital Sunday following "an apparent heart attack," Senate Armed Services Chair Jack Reed (D-Rhode Island) alleged U.S. Senator Tommy Tuberville's (R-Alabama) military promotions hold may have contributed, Politico reports.
Politico notes the Alabama senator "has maintained the blockade over the Pentagon's abortion travel policy, ensnaring more than 300 generals and admirals at the upper rungs of the armed forces."
Reed told the news outlet, "One of the reasons, I think contributed to his condition was he was doing two jobs at once. I've read where he was working from 5 a.m. to 11 p.m. As a result, if he had, as is normal, an assistant, he could switch off."
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to hold office again?
Per the report, he ad…

Newly appointed House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) has a record of opposing military assistance to Ukraine. Since taking charge of the House, he has not outright said he will block Ukraine aid — but he has made clear it will not be coupled to his planned aid package to Israel, claiming the latter is more urgent of a need.
But if Johnson continues to obstruct Ukraine aid, he is headed for a "collision course" with his counterpart in Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY), who is committed to continuing to defend Eastern Europe against Russian aggression, reported Politico on Monday.
According to Burgess Everett, McConnell's outspoken lobbying efforts to sway Republican senators to passing Ukraine relief "is a sharp deviation from his usual more reserved, consensus-building approach" a…

articles.description:
Israel Defence Forces Spokesperson Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Conricus says the mission in Gaza is to engage with Hamas and dismantle each and every stronghold as the military attempts to retrieve hostages. 

“We are doing that in a slow and meticulous order,” he told Sky News Australia. 

“It is totally enmeshed with tunnels, many of them short, tactical tunnels that are just basically fighting positions which allow Hamas to move from one alley to another – emerge and then submerge.

“It is a very challenging battlespace to be in – Hamas has prepared the battlefield unfortunately very well.”

“We are slowly getting to all of them and there are gains achieved each day of fighting.”

articles.description: A new commemorative coin celebrating the King’s 75th birthday and paying tribute to his passion for the natural world has been unveiled by the Royal Mint. To mark the occasion, the Mint is looking for 75 people turning 75 years old this year, to give them a special £5 coin, in honour of the King’s birthday. To honour the King’s lifelong commitment to sustainability, a special birthday coin has also been made from a blend of silver recovered from industrial and medical x-ray films. Those celebrating their 75th birthday in 2023 can submit their name and contact details via the Royal Mint to be in with a chance of receiving an uncirculated £5 commemorative coin. The winners will be drawn at random and asked to provide photographic evidence of age. They will be contacted via email from early December 2023.
articles.title: Royal Mint is giving coins to 75 people turning 75, to mark the King’s birthday

articles.description:
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has gained a considerable amount of ground over Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, according to the latest Newspoll.

In the first major poll since the Voice referendum was defeated, the Coalition now leads Labor on the primary vote.

The poll reports the primary vote for the Coalition is at 37 per cent whilst Labor trails behind now at 35 per cent.

On two-party preferred voting the Coalition has also tightened the gap at 48 per cent, coming in close to Labor’s 52 per cent.

This latest data has marked the closest contest since the election.
articles.title: Newspoll: Peter Dutton overtakes Anthony Albanese on the primary vote

articles.description:
Massive explosions are hitting Gaza City and its surroundings as Israel continues on with its deadliest campaign to destroy Hamas following the terrorist group's unprovoked attack on October 7.

The IDF on Sunday said its troops were “encircling Gaza city” and conducting “widespread strikes”.

Health officials in the Palestinian territory claimed 53 people died in two blasts at refugee camps.

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reaffirmed his rejection for a ceasefire on Sunday until the some 240 hostages taken by Hamas on October 7 are released.

"There will be no ceasefire without the return of the hostages. This should be completely removed from the lexicon," Mr Netanyahu said.

"We say this to our friends and to our enemies. We will simply continue until we defeat them. We have no alternative."
articles.title: Israel launches deadliest attack yet to destroy Hamas

articles.author: Derek Grossman
articles.description:
For the last several months, the Chinese government has steadily ramped up its coercive gray-zone tactics in order to interfere with Philippine civilian resupply missions of troops aboard the BRP Sierra Madre at Second Thomas Shoal in the South China Sea. In 1999, Manila intentionally ran the World War II-era ship aground on this disputed shoal, establishing a permanent military presence, to demonstrate Philippine sovereignty there. Since then, Philippine resupply missions have consistently faced Chinese harassment.  This year, such activities, which are non-kinetic and meant to achieve national objectives without warfare, have clearly intensified. Beijing has shone a military-grade laser
The post China’s Gray-Zone Tactics Show the U.S.-Philippine Alliance Is Working appeared first on War on the Rocks.
articles.title: China’s Gray-Zone Tactics Show the U.S.-Philippine Alliance Is Working

articles.author: James Acton
articles.description:
China’s growing nuclear arsenal has prompted a debate — in think tanks and research institutions and, more quietly, in the bowels of the Pentagon and U.S. Strategic Command —about how the United States should adapt its nuclear posture to the emergence of a second “nuclear peer.” The central issue is the arcane subject of nuclear targeting: the question of what facilities the United States should, in the detached language of nuclear strategists, “hold at risk,” or in plain English, threaten to nuke. America’s current targeting policy is often described as “counterforce.” This term is widely and correctly understood to mean
The post Two Myths about Counterforce appeared first on War on the Rocks.

articles.description:
Taiwanese troops following an undated exercise

 
BBC: The US is quietly arming Taiwan to the teeth 
When US President Joe Biden recently signed off on a $80m (£64.6m) grant to Taiwan for the purchase of American military equipment, China said it "deplores and opposes" what Washington had done. 
To the casual observer it didn't appear a steep sum. It was less than the cost of a single modern fighter jet. Taiwan already has on order more than $14bn worth of US military equipment. Does a miserly $80m more matter? 
While fury is Beijing's default response to any military support for Taiwan, this time something was different. 

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: The flow of arms to Taiwan is massive .... Breaking Down Taiwan’s Arms Backlog, Part 1: Overview and Methodology (CATO). 
 Concerns that this may all backfire are justified .... The US is quietly arming Taiwan against a Chinese invasion — but it could backfire (Business Insider).

 
Update: Here is an interesting read .... How Would China Take Over Taiwan? One of These 5 Strategies (AEI/Bloomberg).
articles.title: Taiwan Is Being Armed 'To The Teeth' By The U.S.

articles.description:
The EMC group, which rejected a 2016 peace deal that disarmed the FARC, has suspended direct peace talks with the Colombian government. Image: JOAQUIN SARMIENTO/AFP

 
Colombia Reports: FARC dissidents suspend peace talks with Colombia’s government

 
Guerrillas vow to continue to uphold ceasefire. 
FARC dissident group EMC said Sunday that it had suspended peace talks, claiming that Colombia’s government has failed to comply with made agreements. 
The guerrillas said that they would uphold a ceasefire that was agreed with the government of President Gustavo Petro three weeks ago. 
According to an EMC press release, the peace talks were suspended because of “processes of militarization” in areas that are largely controlled by units of the FARC dissident organization.

 
Read more ....

 
Update #1: Colombia: FARC dissident group pulls out of peace talks (DW)
 
Update #2: Colombian rebels suspend talks with government (Hurriyet Daily News)

 
WNU Editor: They vow to still continue to uphold the ceasefire for the next 3 months.
articles.title: FARC Dissident Group Pulls Out Of Colombia Peace Talks

Axios: CIA chief visiting Israel and other Middle East nations as war in Gaza grinds on 
CIA director Bill Burns is visiting Israel and other countries in the region this week for talks on the war in Gaza and the efforts to release hostages held by Hamas, two Israeli officials confirmed to Axios.

 
Why it matters: Burns' trip is part of the Biden administration's ongoing engagement with key parties in an effort to get a humanitarian pause in the fighting and prevent a regional war.

articles.description:
BBC: Israel Gaza war: Hamas-run health ministry says Gaza death toll passes 10,000 
The Hamas-run health ministry in Gaza says more than 10,000 people have been killed in the Palestinian territory since Israel started bombing it last month.

More than 4,000 of those killed were children, the ministry said. 
The number surpasses the UN's figure of about 5,400 killed in Gaza in all of Israel's previous conflicts with Hamas since it took control of the territory in 2007.
Israel began bombing Gaza after Hamas killed 1,400 people and kidnapped more than 200 others on 7 October. 
It says it is destroying Hamas infrastructure and killing its fighters so that it will no longer be able to pose a threat to Israel.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: A look at the military situation is in the video belo…
articles.title: Israel - Hamas War -- News Updates November 6, 2023

articles.description:
Armoured vehicles of the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) are seen during their ground operations at a location given as Gaza, as the conflict between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas continues, in this handout image released on November 1, 2023. 
Israel Defense Forces | Reuters

 
CNBC: ‘It’s going to be bloody’: Why Israel’s long war ahead will be nothing like what it’s faced before  
* Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned his country that a “long and difficult war” lay ahead. 
* The IDF is supplementing heavy aerial bombardment of the besieged territory with what’s been described as a ground incursion, the details of which have been kept closely guarded. 
* Prolonged urban combat will bring a slew of deadly challenges for the IDF – and likely some key advantages for Hamas, military analysts say. 
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned his country that a “long and difficult war” lay ahead. 
The Israeli Defense Forces, after launching the largest military mobilization of troops in its history, has now entered into the “second phase” of its war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip. 
The IDF is supplementing heavy aerial bombardment of the besieged territory with what’s been described as a ground incursion, the details of which have been kept closely guarded.
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: The attack by Hamas on October 7th was different in many ways(the size of the attack and the high civilian casualty numbers and kidnapped Israelis). Israel's declaration of war while making it a commitment to completely wipe out Hamas was also new and unprecedented.
Bottom line. Israel is facing urban and attrition warfare coupled with astronomical casualty numbers. And when completed, Gaza is going to look like what Mosul looked like after the Iraqi army was successful in wiping out ISIS. 
So yes. Israel’s long war ahead will be nothing like what it’s faced before
articles.title: Israel’s Long War Ahead Will Be Nothing Like What It’s Faced Before

articles.description:
Reuters: UN leaders say Gaza war must 'stop now' as reported death toll tops 10,000

 
At least 10,022 Palestinians have been killed including 4,104 children in Israeli strikes on Gaza since Oct. 7, the health ministry in Hamas-controlled Gaza said. 
GAZA (Reuters) - U.N. agency leaders saying "enough is enough" demanded a humanitarian ceasefire on Monday nearly a month into Gaza's war, as health authorities in the enclave said the death toll from Israeli strikes now exceeded 10,000. 
Israel has rebuffed mounting international pressure for a ceasefire, saying hostages taken by Hamas militants during their rampage in southern Israel on Oct. 7 should be released first. 
"An entire population is besieged and under attack, denied access to the essentials for survival, bombed in their homes, shelters, hospitals and places of worship. This is unacceptable," the U.N. chiefs said in a joint statement.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: This conflict has become the most dangerous for UN staff in its history .... UN says 88 staff members killed in Gaza, highest ever in single conflict (First Post). 
Hamas Says Gaza Death Toll Now Tops 10,000 
Israeli forces cut off north Gaza as Palestinian death toll passes 10,000 in 4 weeks of war -- AP
 
Hamas says Gaza death toll tops 10,000 as Israel steps up war -- France 24
 
Israeli forces sever north Gaza from rest of strip as Palestinian death toll tops 10,000  -- LA Times 
Israeli forces cut off north Gaza as Palestinian death toll from monthlong war passes 10,000 -- The Hill
articles.title: Hamas Says Gaza Death Toll Now Tops 10,000

articles.description:
DNYUZ/New York Times: Netanyahu suspends a minister who said that dropping a nuclear bomb on Gaza was an option. 
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel took the highly unusual step on Sunday of suspending a far-right minister from his government, after the minister said that dropping a nuclear bomb on Gaza and killing everyone there was “one way” of dealing with the threat from Hamas. 
Mr. Netanyahu’s swift action came amid an immediate and broad outcry over the comments made on Sunday morning by Amichay Eliyahu, the minister of heritage from the ultranationalist Jewish Power party. 
In his remarks, made to a Hebrew radio station, Mr. Eliyahu also said that there was no such thing as noncombatants in Gaza. 
 Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: The debate on Israel using nuclear weapons has been ongoing since the start of the war .... Would Israel Use Its Not-So-Secret Nuclear Arsenal If The War Expands Beyond Gaza? (Zero Hedge). 
Israeli PM Netanyahu Suspends Minister Who Suggested Dropping A Nuclear Bomb On Gaza Is An Option

Libyan renegade general Khalifa Haftar during a reception ceremony upon arrival at a Moscow military airfield on September 26, 2023 [AFP]

 
Bloomberg: Putin’s move to secure Libya bases is new regional challenge for US, European allies 
Russia is moving to expand its military presence in eastern Libya, a plan that could lead to a naval base, giving it a significant foothold on Europe’s southern doorstep. 
A defense accord is being hammered out between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Libya’s eastern military commander Khalifa Haftar following their meeting in Moscow in late September, according to people briefed on the matter, who asked not to be identified discussing sensitive issues.

בימים האחרונים זוהה על ידי מערכות הבקרה והגילוי של חיל-האוויר, טיל שיוט, ששוגר מדרום מזרח אל עבר המרחב האווירי של מדינת ישראל. המערכות עקבו אחרי מסלולו של טיל השיוט והזניקו מטוסי קרב ממערך ה״אדיר״, אשר יירטו אותו בהצלחה. pic.twitter.com/6fP6TnlpTm

The Aviationist: In A First, Israeli F-35I Adir Shoots Down Cruise Missile 
The kill, scored against a missile likely launched from Yemen, is the first interception of this kind by the 5th gen fighter. 
The Israeli Air Force disclosed today that one of its F-35I Adir fighters recently shot down a cruise missile which was about to enter Israeli airspace from the southwest. 
The cruise missile, possibly launched from Yemen, was detected and tracked by the air defense as F-35Is were scrambled to intercept it, scoring the first cruise missile kill by the 5th generation fighter.

 
Read more ....

articles.description:
The Arrow missile-defence system took out a ballistic missile fired over 1,000km away in Yemen © Provided by The Telegraph

  
NBC News: Israel shot down a ballistic missile fired from Yemen, U.S. officials say 

  Israel says that it took down the missile with its Arrow system and that Israeli fighter jets intercepted drones launched from the same direction. 
Militants believed to be Houthi rebels fired a medium-range ballistic missile from Yemen toward Israel on Tuesday, according to two U.S. officials. In a statement, the Israel Defense Forces said the missile was intercepted by Israel’s Arrow air defense system, which was jointly developed by Israel and the U.S. The IDF confirmed that a surface-to-surface missile had been fired toward Israeli territory from the direction of the Red Sea, but not did specify whether it had originated in Yemen.
The U.S. officials said the missile, which had a range of 2,000 kilometers (about 1,240 miles) or more, did not threaten U.S. Navy ships in the Red Sea or U.S. troops or personnel in the area.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: This is how Israel was able to do it .... How Israel shot down a ballistic missile in space for the first time (The Telegraph). 
 Israel’s Arrow Air Defense System Intercepts Ballistic Missile Near The Red Sea

 
In first, Israel’s Arrow air defense system intercepts ballistic missile near Red Sea: IDF -- Breaking Defense
